thread.title: Auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers apologizes for Oscar best picture mixup
thread.title_full: Auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers apologizes for Oscar best picture mixup - The Boston Globe

title: Auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers apologizes for Oscar best picture mixup
text:
Google+
By Sean Smyth Globe Staff February 27, 2017
The 2017 Academy Awards After a stunning mixup, ‘Moonlight’ awarded best picture How the 'Moonlight'-'La La Land' scene unfolded Plenty of sympathy to go around Pricewaterhouse Coopers apologizes for role in miscue Look at who wowed on the red carpet Host Jimmy Kimmel blends political humor with Hollywood teasing Trump was on people’s minds, if not lips, at Oscars Damien Chazelle’s Harvard professors remember him when Hollywood tour group gets surprise side trip to Oscar show Kimmel-Matt Damon ‘feud’ spills across the Oscars stage Winning Iranian director skips show over ‘inhumane’ travel ban Stars wear blue ribbons in support of ACLU Sting pays an emotional tribute to slain N.H. journalist James Foley In Rhode Island, fans cheer native Viola Davis's win Sound engineer wins first Oscar after 21 nominations Notable moments from the 2017 Oscars — other than that one List of winners at the 89th Academy Awards
The auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers issued a statement early Monday stating that it was investigating what led to the the “Moonlight”-“La La Land” mixup during Sunday’s Academy Awards .
“We appreciate the grace with which the nominees, the Academy [of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences], ABC, and [host] Jimmy Kimmel handled the situation,” said a release posted on PwC’s Twitter feed.
Advertisement
“La La Land” initially was announced as the winner for best picture before things took a shocking turn — indeed, it was “Moonlight” that was the top picture.
“The presenters had mistakenly been given the wrong category envelope. . . . We are currently investigating how this could have happened,” the company wrote.
Get The Weekender in your inbox: The Globe's top picks for what to see and do each weekend, in Boston and beyond. Sign The release in full:
pic.twitter.com/oGJkXytnQ2
— PwC LLP (@PwC_LLP) February 27, 2017 The mistake came days after a Huffington Post article on the process for handling the envelopes containing the names of the award-winners, where PwC officials downplayed the possibility of such a mistake.
“It’s so unlikely,” said Brian Cullinan, one of the supervisors of the vote count.
